overview_of_class: COURSE DESCRIPTION: Composers, performers, and musical institutions in Hitler's Germany and Stalin's Russia underwent profound and even traumatic transformations. In this course we will examine the effects of these changes on musical life from the 1920s through the aftermath of World War II. Special topics to be covered include the crackdown by the Soviet government on Sergei Prokofiev and Dmitri Shostakovich in 1936 and again in 1948, the Munich exhibit of "Entartete Musik" (Degenerate Music) in 1938, music in concentration camps, the concept of Internal Exile ("Innere Imigration"), and the controversial careers of figures such as Richard Strauss, Wilhelm Furtwängler, Herbert von Karajan, and Elizabeth Schwarzkopf.
name: Topics in 20th Century Music

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: EVALUATION will be based on attendance (10 pts.), two shorter written assignments (worth 20 pts. each), a research project culminating in a term paper of 8-10 pp. (worth 30 points, due for submission on the last day of class and serving in lieu of a Final Examination) on a topic approved by the instructor no later than Week 4 of the quarter, a brief oral report accompanied by a handout including bibliography, on the same topic as the research project (10 pts.), and class discussion (10 pts.). Students who submit a concert report of a live musical performance which includes repertoire relevant to the course may earn up to 10 extra credit points, provided that they have secured prior permission of the instructor and agree to follow the guidelines provided for such cases.
